title: Myer misled shareholders but they didn't lose any money
text:
In September that year the retailer reported a 21.3 per cent fall in full-year net profit to $77.5 million and the shares fell from $1.40 to 83¢.

The court heard in December 2018 that Myer prepared two different profit forecasts on the same day for the 2015 financial year, with one internal document clinging to a full-year forecast of $101 million while another draft report warned profit could be as low as $90 million.

Former Myer chief executive Bernie Brookes said he had not seen the forecasts and described the reports as incomplete.

On Thursday Federal Court Justice Jonathan Beach ruled the net profit guidance was misleading.

Myer shareholders had claimed there were no reasonable grounds for the $98.5 million forecast because it should have been evident to Myer that costs were rising at a faster rate than revenues and profits would be materially lower.

Investors argued the misleading forecast meant the value of their shares were over-inflated and sought to recover the difference between the price of their shares and what the true value would have been but for the misleading profit projection.

They claimed Myer should have known it would not achieve its $98.5 million profit forecast by November 11, 2014. They pointed to the fact the forecast hinged on sales revenue increasing, even though sales had been going backwards for years, dropping to $3.1 billion by 2014 from $3.3 billion in 2010.

Advertisement

Myer agreed it had told the market it expected a net profit of $98.5 million but denied it had misled or deceived shareholders or witheld material information from the market.

The decision sets a precedent for listed companies which provide profit guidance and their boards, shareholders, insurers, litigation funders and lawyers who run these cases.

Two Myer investors, Christopher and Jacinta Amies, who were trustees of the Amies Superannuation Fund, spearheaded the court case as lead plaintiffs in the class action through trustee company TPT Patrol.

Barristers Norman O'Bryan, SC, and Michael Symons with firm Portfolio Law fought the case on behalf of Myer shareholders, while barristers Ian Waller, QC, and Paul Liondas with law firm Clayton Utz defended Myer.

The plaintiffs' case was funded Australian Funding Partners, which is run by ex-MinterEllison partner Mark Elliott. Mr Elliott had originally attempted to sue Myer as the lead plaintiff, litigation funder and lawyer on the case before his case was thrown out as an abuse of process.

More to come
description: Myer misled shareholders over its forecast 2015 profits and breached its disclosure obligations but shareholders suffered no loss because "hard-edged" analysts didn't believe the forecast, a court has found.
